posts.title: Why Is My iPhone Screen Flickering? Common Causes and Fixes
posts.excerpt: Discover the most common reasons your iPhone screen flickers and learn when you can fix it yourself versus when to seek professional repair.
posts.content:
If your iPhone screen has started flickering, you're not alone. This is one of the most common issues we see at Star Tech, and it can range from a minor software glitch to a sign of hardware damage.

Software-Related Causes

Before assuming the worst, try these simple fixes. Sometimes a flickering screen is caused by software bugs, especially after a major iOS update. Start by restarting your iPhone - hold the power button and volume button together, then slide to power off. Wait 30 seconds and turn it back on.

Another common culprit is Auto-Brightness. Go to Settings > Accessibility > Display & Text Size and toggle off Auto-Brightness. If the flickering stops, you've found your issue.

Low battery can also cause display issues. If your battery health is below 80%, the phone may struggle to power the display consistently, causing flickers especially when the battery is low.

Hardware-Related Causes

If software fixes don't work, you're likely dealing with hardware problems. The most common is a damaged or loose display connector. This often happens after a drop, even if there's no visible damage to the screen.

Water damage is another frequent cause. Even "water-resistant" iPhones can suffer internal corrosion that affects display connections. If your phone has been exposed to moisture, this could be the culprit.

On older iPhones (particularly iPhone X and 11 series), the display ribbon cable can wear out over time, causing intermittent flickering that gets worse.

When to Seek Professional Help

If basic troubleshooting doesn't resolve the issue, it's time to bring your phone in for diagnosis. Continuing to use a phone with hardware-related flickering can lead to complete screen failure. At Star Tech, we offer free diagnostics to identify the exact cause and provide a quote before any repairs.

Most screen-related repairs can be completed same-day, and we use quality parts backed by our repair warranty.

posts.title: 5 Signs Your iPhone Battery Needs Replacing
posts.excerpt: Learn the telltale signs that your iPhone battery is failing and why replacing it can make your phone feel brand new again.
posts.content:
iPhone batteries are designed to retain up to 80% of their original capacity after 500 complete charge cycles. But how do you know when yours has reached the end of its life? Here are five clear signs.

1. Your Battery Health Is Below 80%

The easiest way to check is right in your settings. Go to Settings > Battery > Battery Health & Charging. If Maximum Capacity shows less than 80%, Apple considers your battery "degraded" and it's time for a replacement.

2. Your Phone Dies Unexpectedly

Does your iPhone shut down at 20% battery? Or even 40%? This is a classic sign of a worn battery. The battery can no longer accurately report its charge level, and what it thinks is 20% is actually empty.

3. Your Phone Gets Hot

All phones generate some heat, but if yours gets uncomfortably warm during normal use (not gaming or video calls), the battery may be working overtime to deliver power. This is both a symptom of battery wear and something that accelerates further degradation.

4. Slow Performance

Apple's performance management feature throttles your CPU when the battery can't deliver peak power. You might notice apps taking longer to open, keyboard lag, or slower scrolling. While you can disable this in settings, doing so risks unexpected shutdowns.

5. Physical Swelling

This is the most serious sign. If your screen appears to be lifting away from the frame, or the back of your phone is bulging, stop using it immediately. A swollen battery is a safety hazard and needs professional replacement right away.

Why Replace Instead of Upgrade?

A new battery costs a fraction of a new phone and can add 2-3 more years to your device's life. At Star Tech, iPhone battery replacements typically take under an hour and come with a warranty. It's the most cost-effective way to restore your phone's performance.

posts.title: Dropped Your Phone in Water? Here's What to Do (and What Not to Do)
posts.excerpt: Quick action can save a water-damaged phone. Learn the right steps to take immediately and the common myths that can make things worse.
posts.content:
Water and electronics don't mix, but accidents happen. Whether your phone took a dive in the toilet, pool, or washing machine, what you do in the first few minutes matters most.

Do This Immediately

Get it out and power it off. Every second underwater increases the risk of damage. Once retrieved, hold the power button and turn it completely off. Do not try to charge it or plug anything in.

Remove what you can. Take off any case, remove the SIM tray, and if your phone has a removable battery (rare these days), take it out. The goal is to let air reach as many openings as possible.

Shake out excess water. Gently shake the phone with the charging port facing down to let gravity drain water from the ports and speakers.

Dry the exterior. Use a lint-free cloth to wipe down every surface. Pay special attention to ports and speaker grilles.

What NOT to Do

Don't use rice. This is the biggest myth in phone repair. Rice does not absorb moisture effectively from inside a phone, and the dust and starch can actually clog ports and cause additional problems. Studies have shown phones dry just as well in open air.

Don't use a hair dryer. Heat can damage internal components and push water deeper into the device. The same goes for putting it in an oven or microwave (yes, people try this).

Don't charge it. Applying power to wet electronics causes short circuits. This is how minor water exposure becomes permanent damage.

The Best Approach

After initial drying, place your phone in front of a fan or in a dry, warm area for 24-48 hours. Silica gel packets (the ones that come in shoe boxes) are actually effective if you have them handy.

However, the safest option is professional cleaning. Water damage is often invisible - corrosion starts immediately and spreads over days and weeks. At Star Tech, we open the device, displace any remaining moisture with specialized solutions, and clean corrosion before it causes permanent damage.

If your phone was submerged for more than a few seconds, or was in salt water, we strongly recommend professional assessment even if it seems to be working fine.

posts.title: iPhone Not Charging? It Might Just Need a Clean
posts.excerpt: Before paying for repairs, learn how pocket lint and debris could be the simple reason your iPhone won't charge properly.
posts.content:
You plug in your iPhone and nothing happens. Or maybe it charges intermittently, only at certain angles, or painfully slowly. Before assuming the worst, there's a surprisingly common cause that's easy to fix.

The Hidden Culprit: Pocket Lint

Your iPhone lives in your pocket or bag, collecting tiny fibers of lint and dust every day. These particles get pushed into the charging port and compressed every time you plug in your cable. Over months, this builds up into a compressed layer that prevents the cable from making proper contact.

How to Check

Grab a flashlight and look inside your charging port. If you see fuzzy buildup at the back, you've found the problem. The port should look clean with visible gold contacts.

Safe Cleaning Methods

The safest tool is a wooden or plastic toothpick. Never use metal, as it can damage the delicate pins inside the port. Gently scrape along the back wall of the port, then work along the sides. You might be surprised how much compacted lint comes out.

For stubborn debris, a soft anti-static brush (like those used for camera lenses) can help. Short bursts of compressed air can also work, but hold the can upright to avoid moisture.

After cleaning, try your cable again. In many cases, this simple fix restores full charging functionality.

When It's Actually Hardware Damage

If cleaning doesn't help, the port itself may be damaged. Common issues include:

  • Bent or broken pins from forcing cables in at angles
  • Corrosion from moisture exposure
  • General wear after years of use

Charging port replacement is a straightforward repair that we complete same-day at Star Tech. We also test your battery at the same time, as charging issues can sometimes indicate battery problems rather than port damage.

posts.title: Can You Keep Using a Phone with a Cracked Screen?
posts.excerpt: Your phone still works with that crack, but is it safe? Learn the risks of delaying screen repair and when it becomes urgent.
posts.content:
We've all seen people using phones with spider-webbed screens. Maybe you're doing it right now. While it's tempting to put off repair costs, here's what you should know about the risks.

The Immediate Risks

Cuts and injuries. Small glass fragments can break off with use, especially around the edges. These can cut your fingers, cheek, or ear during calls. Even tiny shards can cause painful splinters.

Moisture and dust entry. Cracks compromise the seal protecting internal components. Even "water-resistant" phones lose that protection once the screen is damaged. Perth's coastal humidity can accelerate corrosion inside your device.

Progressive Damage

What starts as a small crack often spreads. Temperature changes cause glass to expand and contract, extending cracks across the screen. Daily pressure in your pocket adds stress.

Cracks can also affect touch sensitivity. You might notice dead spots, ghost touches, or areas that don't respond. This gets worse over time as the digitizer layer beneath the glass degrades.

When It's Urgent

Certain types of damage need immediate attention:

  • Visible display damage - colored lines, black spots, or flickering indicate LCD/OLED damage beneath the glass
  • Touch malfunctions - ghost touches can make calls, send messages, or even factory reset your phone without your input
  • Battery visibility - if you can see any internal components, stop using the phone immediately

Cost of Waiting

Here's the irony: delaying repair often costs more. A simple glass replacement might become a full screen assembly replacement if the underlying display gets damaged. Water intrusion can affect the motherboard, turning a $150 repair into a $400+ job or total loss.

At Star Tech, we offer free assessments to let you know exactly what's needed. Same-day screen repairs are available for most popular phone models, getting you back to a fully functional device quickly.

posts.title: Samsung vs iPhone: Which Costs More to Repair?
posts.excerpt: Comparing repair costs between the two most popular smartphone brands and what factors affect the price you'll pay.
posts.content:
When choosing between Samsung and Apple, long-term repair costs rarely factor into the decision. But they probably should. Here's how the two brands compare when things go wrong.

Screen Repairs

Samsung flagship screens typically cost more to replace than equivalent iPhones. The curved "Edge" displays on many Galaxy models require more complex installation and pricier parts. A Galaxy S24 Ultra screen replacement can run 20-30% higher than an iPhone 15 Pro Max.

However, Samsung's mid-range A-series phones are among the most affordable to repair, often cheaper than budget iPhones.

Battery Replacements

Battery costs are similar between brands, with Samsung slightly cheaper on average. The difference is usually $10-20. However, Samsung's adhesive makes batteries slightly more labor-intensive to replace on certain models.

Charging Ports

This is where design philosophy matters. On most Samsung phones, the charging port is a separate module that can be replaced independently. On iPhones, it's often integrated with other components. Samsung port repairs typically cost less as a result.

Parts Availability

Apple's tight control over parts has loosened in recent years, but Samsung parts are generally more readily available from multiple sources. This competition helps keep Samsung repair prices down.

For newer models of either brand, parts take time to reach the repair market after launch. Expect higher prices for phones released within the last 6 months.

The Verdict

Neither brand is consistently cheaper to repair. iPhone repairs are more predictable in cost, while Samsung varies widely between flagship and budget models. The curved screens on premium Samsung phones are the most expensive common repair.

At Star Tech, we repair both brands daily and can give you accurate quotes for your specific model. We also offer a price-match guarantee if you find a lower quote for the same quality repair in Perth.

posts.title: Why Does My Phone Get So Hot? Causes and Solutions
posts.excerpt: Understanding why your phone overheats and when it's a sign of a problem that needs professional attention.
posts.content:
Your phone is essentially a pocket computer, and like any computer, it generates heat. But how hot is too hot, and when should you be concerned?

Normal Heating Situations

Some heat is completely normal during:

  • Gaming or running intensive apps
  • Video calls or recording video
  • Fast charging or wireless charging
  • Using GPS navigation
  • Initial setup or restoring from backup

In these situations, your phone's processor is working hard. It should cool down within 10-15 minutes of stopping the activity.

Warning Signs

Be concerned if your phone:

  • Gets hot during basic tasks like texting or browsing
  • Displays a temperature warning message
  • Feels hot when idle or overnight
  • Gets hot in the same spot every time (often indicates battery issue)

Common Causes of Excessive Heat

Battery degradation is the most common hardware cause. As batteries age, they become less efficient and generate more heat during discharge and charging. Check your battery health in settings.

Background apps can keep your processor busy without you realizing it. Check which apps are using the most battery - high battery usage often correlates with heat generation.

Software bugs occasionally cause runaway processes. A restart often fixes this. If the problem persists after restarting and updating your OS, it might be a deeper issue.

Environmental factors matter too. Leaving your phone in direct sunlight or in a hot car can push temperatures to dangerous levels. Phone cases trap heat - remove yours if overheating is frequent.

When It's Serious

A phone that's too hot to hold comfortably needs attention. If the heat is localized near the battery (usually the upper back half of the phone), this is particularly concerning.

Continuing to use an overheating phone can cause permanent damage to internal components and, in extreme cases, battery failure. Bring it in for a free diagnostic check at Star Tech to identify the root cause.

posts.title: Face ID Not Working? Here's How to Fix It
posts.excerpt: Troubleshooting the most common Face ID problems and understanding when hardware repair is necessary.
posts.content:
Face ID is convenient when it works, frustrating when it doesn't. Before assuming your TrueDepth camera needs repair, try these troubleshooting steps.

Basic Checks First

Clean the sensors. The Face ID array is in the notch or Dynamic Island at the top of your screen. Smudges, dirt, or screen protectors covering these sensors can prevent recognition. Clean with a soft, lint-free cloth.

Check your setup. Go to Settings > Face ID & Passcode. Make sure Face ID is enabled for the features you're trying to use. Try setting up an "Alternate Appearance" if you've significantly changed your look.

Reset Face ID. Sometimes starting fresh helps. In Face ID settings, tap "Reset Face ID" and set it up again. Make sure you're in good lighting and position your face within the frame correctly.

Environmental Factors

Face ID struggles in certain conditions:

  • Very bright sunlight (infrared interference)
  • Very dark environments
  • Certain sunglasses that block infrared
  • Face coverings (though recent iOS versions have improved this)

If Face ID fails in specific conditions but works otherwise, this is normal behavior rather than a defect.

After Screen Repairs

Face ID is notoriously sensitive to screen replacements. The TrueDepth components must be precisely aligned, and the ambient light sensor needs recalibration. If Face ID stopped working after a repair elsewhere, that repair may not have been done correctly.

At Star Tech, we have the tools to properly calibrate Face ID components after screen repairs - something many repair shops skip.

Hardware Failure Signs

If Face ID suddenly stopped working without any drops or damage, and troubleshooting doesn't help, hardware failure is likely. Common causes include:

  • Flood illuminator or infrared camera failure
  • Damage from drops (even without visible screen damage)
  • Water damage affecting the sensor array

Face ID repairs are complex because Apple pairs components to individual phones. We offer diagnostic services to determine if repair is possible or if component replacement is needed.

posts.title: iPad Won't Turn On? Try These Fixes Before Panicking
posts.excerpt: A dead iPad isn't always dead. Learn the common causes and solutions for an iPad that won't power on.
posts.content:
Pressing the power button on your iPad and seeing nothing is alarming. But before you panic about data loss or expensive repairs, there are several things to try.

It's Probably Just Deeply Discharged

This is by far the most common cause. If an iPad sits unused with a low battery, it can discharge to a point where it won't respond at all - not even showing the charging indicator initially.

The fix: Connect to power using a known-good cable and adapter. Then wait. It can take 15-30 minutes before a deeply discharged iPad shows any sign of life. Don't keep pressing buttons - just leave it connected.

Force Restart

If the iPad has power but seems frozen on a black screen:

iPads with Face ID: Quickly press and release Volume Up, then Volume Down, then press and hold the Power button until the Apple logo appears (about 10-15 seconds).

iPads with Home Button: Hold both the Home button and Power button together for at least 10 seconds until the Apple logo appears.

Check Your Charging Setup

iPads need adequate power to charge - the small 5W cubes that come with iPhones often aren't enough. Use the adapter that came with your iPad, or any 18W+ USB-C adapter.

Inspect your cable for damage, especially near the connectors where bending causes internal wire breakage. Try a different cable if possible.

Check the charging port for lint and debris - iPads accumulate pocket lint just like phones.

Screen vs. Device Failure

Sometimes the iPad is actually on, but the screen isn't working. Try this: connect to power, wait a few minutes, then try triggering Siri ("Hey Siri") or playing a sound. If you hear any response, the device works but the display has failed.

When to Seek Help

If none of these steps work after thorough attempts, hardware failure is likely. Common culprits include dead batteries (especially in iPads 3+ years old), failed charging ports, or logic board issues. At Star Tech, we offer free diagnosis to identify the exact problem before you commit to any repair costs.

posts.title: PS4/PS5 No Signal? HDMI Port Issues Explained
posts.excerpt: Understanding why gaming consoles lose video output and what can be done to fix HDMI-related problems.
posts.content:
You turn on your PlayStation, the light turns on, but your TV shows "No Signal." This is one of the most common console repairs we see, and it's almost always related to the HDMI port.

Common Causes

Physical damage to the port is the leading cause. Tripping over the HDMI cable, moving the console with the cable attached, or inserting cables at an angle can bend or break the pins inside the port.

Look inside the HDMI port with a flashlight. You should see a row of small gold pins. Bent, broken, or pushed-back pins are visible signs of damage.

Worn ports develop from repeated cable insertion/removal. The port can become loose, creating intermittent connections.

Electrical damage can occur from power surges or using damaged HDMI cables. This might damage the HDMI controller chip on the motherboard, not just the port itself.

Troubleshooting Steps

Before assuming the port is damaged:

  • Try a different HDMI cable (cables fail more often than ports)
  • Try a different HDMI input on your TV
  • Try a different TV entirely
  • Boot into Safe Mode (hold power button until you hear two beeps) to reset video settings

The Repair Process

HDMI port replacement requires micro-soldering - the port is soldered directly to the motherboard with dozens of tiny pins. This isn't a DIY repair and requires professional equipment and training.

At Star Tech, we perform HDMI port replacements on PS4 and PS5 consoles. The repair involves removing the old port, cleaning the solder pads, and installing a new port with precision alignment. We also test for HDMI controller chip damage, which sometimes requires additional component-level repair.

Prevention Tips

To avoid future HDMI port issues:

  • Never move your console with the cable attached
  • Insert cables straight, never at an angle
  • Route cables to avoid tension or pulling
  • Use a surge protector to prevent electrical damage

posts.title: iPhone Speaker Sounds Muffled or Quiet? Here's Why
posts.excerpt: Before replacing your speaker, try these cleaning tips that fix most iPhone audio problems.
posts.content:
If your iPhone's speaker sounds muffled, quiet, or distorted, the problem is usually simpler than you think. In most cases, it's not a failing speaker - it's a dirty one.

Where the Dirt Hides

Your iPhone has speaker grilles at the bottom (and at the top earpiece). These small openings accumulate dust, pocket lint, and debris over time. The buildup blocks sound, making your speaker seem weak.

Safe Cleaning Methods

Soft brush: A clean, dry toothbrush with soft bristles works well. Brush across the speaker grilles gently to dislodge debris. Work at an angle to sweep particles away rather than pushing them in.

Painter's tape: Press a small piece of tape over the speaker holes, then peel away. The adhesive pulls out particles lodged in the grilles. Repeat several times.

Compressed air: Use short bursts held several inches away. Don't blast directly into the port at close range, as this can damage the speaker membrane.

What Not to Do

Avoid sharp objects like needles or toothpicks directly in the speaker grille - you can easily puncture the mesh or membrane. Don't use liquids or wet cloths directly on speakers. Skip the vacuum cleaner, as the suction can damage speaker components.

Software Checks

While your speaker is physical, software issues can affect audio too:

  • Check that volume is up and the phone isn't in silent mode
  • Restart your phone to clear audio glitches
  • Check Settings > Accessibility > Audio/Visual for balance settings
  • Disconnect from any Bluetooth devices that might be capturing audio

When It's Hardware

If cleaning doesn't help and software is ruled out, the speaker may have failed. Common causes include water damage, drops, or simply age. Speaker replacement is a straightforward repair - we typically complete it within an hour at Star Tech, and it's one of the more affordable iPhone repairs.

posts.title: MacBook Not Charging? Troubleshooting Guide
posts.excerpt: From simple fixes to hardware issues, learn what causes MacBook charging problems and how to resolve them.
posts.content:
A MacBook that won't charge is essentially useless once the battery dies. Let's work through the potential causes from simplest to most complex.

Check the Basics

The charger: MagSafe and USB-C chargers can fail. Look for frayed cables, bent pins (MagSafe), or debris in connectors. Try a different charger if you have access to one.

The outlet: Yes, really. Try a different power outlet or power strip. We've seen many "dead MacBooks" that were just plugged into switched-off outlets.

The connection: For MagSafe, make sure the connector sits flush and the LED illuminates. For USB-C, try both ports if your MacBook has two. Check for debris in the ports themselves.

Reset SMC

The System Management Controller handles power management. Resetting it often fixes charging issues:

MacBooks with T2 chip (2018-2020): Shut down, hold power button for 10 seconds, release, wait a few seconds, then turn on normally.

MacBooks with Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3): Simply shut down and restart - there's no separate SMC reset needed.

Older MacBooks: Shut down, hold Shift+Control+Option+Power for 10 seconds, release all keys, then turn on.

Battery Health

Click the Apple menu > System Settings > Battery. Check the Battery Health section. If it shows "Service Recommended," your battery is significantly degraded and may not charge properly.

Software Updates

Occasionally, macOS bugs affect charging behavior. Make sure your system is updated to the latest version.

Hardware Issues

If none of the above helps, you're likely dealing with:

  • Failed battery - MacBook batteries last 3-5 years typically
  • Charging port damage - especially common on USB-C MacBooks
  • Logic board issues - power delivery components can fail

At Star Tech, we diagnose MacBook charging issues for free and can replace batteries or charging components on most models.

posts.title: Xbox Keeps Overheating and Shutting Down? Causes and Fixes
posts.excerpt: Understanding why your Xbox overheats and how proper maintenance can prevent automatic shutdowns.
posts.content:
Modern gaming consoles run hot, and they have thermal protection that shuts them down before damage occurs. If your Xbox is frequently shutting down from overheating, there's usually a fixable cause.

Location Matters

First, check your console's placement:

  • Is it in an enclosed entertainment center with poor airflow?
  • Are the vents blocked by other objects, walls, or dust?
  • Is it sitting on carpet, which blocks bottom ventilation?
  • Is it near a heat source like a radiator or in direct sunlight?

Consoles need open space around all vents. Most Xbox shutdowns are solved simply by improving ventilation.

Dust Buildup

After 1-2 years of use, internal dust accumulation is almost guaranteed. Dust coats the heatsink and blocks airflow, making cooling far less effective.

You can clean external vents with compressed air, but internal cleaning requires opening the console. For Xbox Series X, this can be done with basic tools. Xbox Series S has a more compact design that's trickier to clean internally.

Thermal Paste Degradation

The thermal paste between the processor and heatsink deteriorates over time - typically after 3-5 years. When it dries out, heat transfer becomes inefficient and the console runs increasingly hot.

Replacing thermal paste requires disassembly, cleaning off old paste, and applying fresh compound. This is a common service we perform on gaming consoles.

Fan Failure

Listen when your console is running. You should hear fan noise that increases under load. If the fan is silent, making grinding noises, or running at maximum constantly, it may be failing.

A failed fan means no active cooling at all - the console will shut down almost immediately under any gaming load.

Professional Service

If basic environmental fixes don't solve the overheating, internal maintenance is needed. At Star Tech, we offer console cleaning services that include dust removal, thermal paste replacement, and fan testing. This typically adds years of life to a console that's been overheating.

posts.title: What Is Screen Burn-In? Can It Be Fixed?
posts.excerpt: Understanding image retention and burn-in on Samsung and OLED phone screens - what causes it and what can be done.
posts.content:
If you notice faint ghost images on your Samsung's display - maybe the navigation bar or keyboard outline visible even on other screens - you're experiencing burn-in. Let's understand what it is and your options.

What Causes Burn-In

OLED displays (used in most Samsung flagships) create light by illuminating individual pixels. When the same image sits on screen for extended periods, those pixels degrade faster than surrounding ones, creating a permanent afterimage.

Common burn-in patterns include:

  • Navigation bar at the bottom
  • Status bar at the top (battery, clock, signal icons)
  • Keyboard outline
  • App interfaces used for hours daily (social media, games)

Burn-In vs. Image Retention

Temporary image retention looks like burn-in but fades after a few minutes of displaying other content. True burn-in is permanent pixel damage that doesn't go away.

To test: display a solid color (gray works best) across the entire screen. If you see ghost images, it's burn-in.

Can It Be Fixed?

Honest answer: not really. Burn-in is physical pixel degradation. Those pixels are damaged and cannot be restored to original condition.

"Burn-in fix" apps and videos attempt to even out wear by running patterns that stress the non-burned pixels to match. This might make burn-in less noticeable temporarily but actually accelerates overall screen degradation.

Prevention Is Key

To minimize burn-in risk:

  • Use shorter screen timeout settings
  • Lower brightness when possible
  • Enable navigation gesture controls instead of static buttons
  • Vary your content - don't leave static images displayed for hours
  • Use dark mode (fewer lit pixels = less wear)

When to Replace

If burn-in significantly impacts your experience, screen replacement is the only real fix. At Star Tech, we replace Samsung OLED screens and can show you exactly what kind of display quality you'll get before committing to the repair.

posts.title: Can Data Be Recovered from a Broken Phone?
posts.excerpt: Understanding your options for recovering photos, messages, and data from a phone that won't turn on.
posts.content:
When your phone dies unexpectedly, the device itself might be replaceable, but your photos, messages, and memories feel irreplaceable. Let's discuss what's actually possible with data recovery.

It Depends on What's Broken

Data recovery success depends entirely on which components have failed:

Screen only: Good news - if just the screen is damaged but the phone still powers on, your data is almost certainly intact. We can either replace the screen so you can access normally, or connect a display output (on some phones) to recover data before repair.

Battery or charging: If the phone won't power on due to battery or charging issues, the storage is usually unaffected. Replacing these components gives full access to data.

Water damage: Success varies widely. If caught early and properly cleaned, data can often be recovered. Severe corrosion affecting storage chips reduces chances significantly.

Logic board failure: More complex. If storage chips are intact, specialist data recovery services can sometimes read them directly. This is expensive but possible.

The Encryption Challenge

Modern phones encrypt all data by default. On iPhones, data cannot be accessed without the device booting up successfully and being unlocked. This means physical chip reading doesn't work for encrypted iOS devices.

Android encryption varies by manufacturer and settings, but most modern Samsungs and Pixels have similar protection.

Before Disaster Strikes

This is really a case where prevention matters:

  • Enable iCloud or Google backup - automatic, continuous protection
  • Periodically backup to computer as secondary protection
  • Check your backup is actually working (go to settings and verify last backup date)

What We Can Do

At Star Tech, we assess data recovery possibilities for free. In many cases, repair alone restores access to everything. For more complex cases, we'll give you honest advice about whether recovery is feasible and what it might cost.

posts.title: Should You Repair or Replace Your Phone? A Practical Guide
posts.excerpt: When does it make sense to fix your phone versus putting that money toward a new one? A realistic breakdown.
posts.content:
You've got a broken phone and you're weighing your options. Repair isn't always the right choice, and neither is replacement. Here's how to decide.

The 50% Rule

A common guideline: if repair costs more than 50% of the phone's current value, replacement often makes more sense. But this oversimplifies things.

When Repair Makes Sense

Your phone is 1-2 years old: A $200 screen repair on a two-year-old flagship that still performs well and gets software updates is usually worth it.

Single issue: If everything else works perfectly, fixing one component gives you a fully functional device.

Data and convenience: Your current phone has everything set up. A new phone means hours of setup, app logins, and learning quirks.

Environmental consideration: Extending a phone's life by a year or two reduces electronic waste.

When Replacement Makes Sense

Multiple issues: Cracked screen AND battery problems AND slow performance? Multiple repairs stack up fast.

Phone is 4+ years old: Older phones may not receive security updates, and performance gap with modern apps becomes noticeable.

Repair cost approaches new phone prices: Some repairs (logic board, severe water damage) can cost $400+. At that point, a new budget phone or quality used phone makes more sense.

You wanted to upgrade anyway: Sometimes a broken phone is just the push you needed.

The Math

Consider cost per remaining month of use:

Example: Your 2-year-old phone needs a $150 screen repair. It can reasonably last another 2 years. That's $150 ÷ 24 months = $6.25/month for a phone you already know and like.

A new $800 phone over 4 years = $16.67/month, plus the hassle of setting everything up again.

Get a Quote First

Don't guess repair costs. At Star Tech, we provide free quotes so you can make an informed decision. Sometimes what seems like a major repair is actually affordable, and vice versa.

posts.title: Nintendo Switch Joy-Con Drift: What Causes It and Can It Be Fixed?
posts.excerpt: Understanding the widespread Joy-Con drift issue, why it happens, and your options for fixing it.
posts.content:
Joy-Con drift is so common that Nintendo faced a class-action lawsuit over it. If your Switch's character moves on its own or the cursor creeps across menus without input, you're experiencing this infamous issue.

What Causes Drift

The Joy-Con uses small analog stick mechanisms that rely on graphite pads making contact with metal contacts. Over time:

  • The graphite wears down from friction
  • Dust and debris accumulate inside the mechanism
  • The contacts become less precise

This is fundamentally a design issue - the components are undersized for the amount of use they receive.

DIY Fixes (Sometimes Work)

Calibration: Go to System Settings > Controllers > Calibrate Control Sticks. This sometimes helps with minor drift.

Compressed air: Lift the rubber skirt around the stick and spray compressed air underneath. This can dislodge debris causing drift.

Contact cleaner: Electronic contact cleaner (not WD-40) under the stick skirt can temporarily restore proper contact. Results vary and often need repeating.

Permanent Fixes

The only real fix is replacing the analog stick module itself. This involves:

  • Opening the Joy-Con (tri-wing screwdriver needed)
  • Desoldering the old stick (or using a no-solder replacement kit)
  • Installing a new module

New stick modules cost around $5-10, but the repair requires some skill. We see many Joy-Cons damaged by attempted DIY repairs.

Professional Repair

At Star Tech, Joy-Con drift repair is one of our most common gaming services. We replace the analog stick module with quality parts, and the repair typically takes less than an hour.

Prevention

Unfortunately, drift seems somewhat inevitable with heavy use. However:

  • Store Joy-Cons away from dust when not in use
  • Don't click the stick in aggressively (L3 function)
  • Consider a Pro Controller for long gaming sessions to reduce Joy-Con wear

posts.title: What Is True Tone and Why Does It Disappear After Screen Repair?
posts.excerpt: Understanding iPhone's True Tone feature and how to ensure it's preserved when getting your screen replaced.
posts.content:
If you've had an iPhone screen replaced and noticed True Tone is now missing from your Display settings, you're not alone. This is one of the most common complaints after third-party screen repairs.

What True Tone Does

True Tone uses ambient light sensors to detect the color temperature of your environment and adjusts the display to match. Under warm incandescent lighting, your screen takes on a warmer tone. Under cool fluorescent lights, it shifts cooler.

The effect is subtle but significant for eye comfort. Without it, your screen might look "too blue" or harsh, especially at night.

Why It Disappears

True Tone calibration data is stored in a chip on the original screen assembly and paired to your specific iPhone. When a screen is replaced:

  • If the repair shop doesn't transfer this data to the new screen, True Tone is lost
  • If a non-genuine screen is used without proper pairing, True Tone won't work
  • Some cheap replacement screens lack the hardware to support True Tone at all

Can It Be Restored?

Yes, with the right equipment. Professional repair shops with proper tools can:

  • Transfer True Tone data from your original screen to a new one
  • Restore True Tone functionality to properly equipped replacement screens

This requires specialized programming hardware that many shops don't invest in.

What to Ask Before Screen Repair

Before agreeing to screen repair anywhere, ask:

  • "Will True Tone still work after the repair?"
  • "Do you have equipment to transfer/restore True Tone calibration?"
  • "Is the replacement screen True Tone compatible?"

A shop that can't answer these questions confidently may leave you with diminished functionality.

At Star Tech

We have the equipment to preserve True Tone functionality on iPhone screen replacements. We also use quality screens that support Apple's display features. If you've had a repair elsewhere that disabled True Tone, we can often restore it.

posts.title: Laptop Running Slow? An SSD Upgrade Can Make It Feel New
posts.excerpt: Why replacing your hard drive with an SSD is the single best upgrade for an aging laptop, and what to expect.
posts.content:
If your laptop takes forever to boot, programs are slow to open, and everything feels sluggish, there's a good chance an SSD upgrade will transform it.

Why Old Laptops Slow Down

Traditional hard drives (HDDs) are the bottleneck in most laptops over 3-4 years old. While processors and RAM have gotten faster, HDDs still spin at the same speeds they did a decade ago.

Modern software assumes SSD speeds. Windows, browsers, and applications are optimized for fast storage access. On an old HDD, everything queues up waiting for the slow disk.

What an SSD Changes

SSDs have no moving parts and access data almost instantly. Typical improvements:

  • Boot time: 2-3 minutes → 15-30 seconds
  • Program launches: 30-60 seconds → 2-5 seconds
  • File transfers: 3-5x faster
  • Overall responsiveness: No more "freezing" when multiple tasks compete for disk access

Many people describe it as getting a new computer.

Is Your Laptop Eligible?

Most laptops made in the last 10 years can accept an SSD upgrade. Some considerations:

  • 2.5" SATA SSDs replace traditional HDDs directly in most laptops
  • M.2 NVMe SSDs are faster but require a compatible slot (most laptops 2015+)
  • Ultrabooks and Macs may have soldered storage that can't be upgraded

What About My Data?

We clone your existing drive to the new SSD. When you boot up, everything is exactly where you left it - same programs, files, settings, and even desktop icons. Just faster.

Cost vs. New Laptop

An SSD upgrade typically costs $150-250 including installation and data transfer. Compare that to $800+ for a new laptop, plus the time to set everything up again.

If your laptop is otherwise functional - keyboard works, screen is good, battery is acceptable - an SSD upgrade often makes more sense than replacement.

At Star Tech, we can assess your laptop and recommend whether an SSD upgrade is right for your situation. We stock common sizes and can usually complete upgrades same-day.

posts.title: How Often Should You Replace Your Phone Battery?
posts.excerpt: Understanding battery lifespan, optimal replacement timing, and how to extend battery health as long as possible.
posts.content:
Phone batteries don't last forever. But with proper care, you can maximize their lifespan and time replacements for when they're actually needed.

Typical Battery Lifespan

Most phone batteries are designed for 500 complete charge cycles while maintaining 80% capacity. A charge cycle is using 100% of capacity (not necessarily in one charge - two days of 50% usage equals one cycle).

For average users, this translates to:

  • Light users: 3-4 years before noticeable degradation
  • Average users: 2-3 years
  • Heavy users: 1.5-2 years

Signs It's Time to Replace

Beyond the battery health percentage in settings, watch for:

  • Can't make it through a normal day anymore
  • Phone shuts down unexpectedly (especially in cold weather)
  • Phone gets hot during charging or normal use
  • Slow or inconsistent charging
  • Any physical bulging (replace immediately)

Extending Battery Life

Some habits help batteries last longer:

Avoid extremes: Don't regularly drain to 0% or charge to 100%. The 20-80% range is easiest on batteries.

Avoid heat: Heat is batteries' worst enemy. Don't leave your phone in hot cars, avoid wireless charging in hot environments, and remove cases during intensive charging.

Use appropriate chargers: Fast charging generates more heat. For overnight charging, slower is actually better for battery longevity.

Don't Wait Too Long

Some people push batteries until they barely function. This creates problems:

  • Extremely degraded batteries can swell, damaging screens
  • Unexpected shutdowns risk data corruption
  • Performance throttling makes phones frustratingly slow

Replacing around 75-80% capacity is the sweet spot - still functional for emergencies, but noticeably improved daily experience with a new battery.

At Star Tech, we stock batteries for most popular Samsung and iPhone models for same-day replacement. We also test your charging system to make sure a new battery will perform optimally.
